message: As we enter this New Year, we reflect on the past and look forward to a promising year ahead, with trust in the power of the American spirit and confidence in our purpose. America certainly has some challenges ahead, next year and beyond, but history tells us that by working together, we can overcome any obstacle. I believe our future is very bright!  Thank you for the feedback and input you’ve provided here on my Facebook page. I look forward to keeping these conversations going into the New Year, as well as seeing all of you when I am out and about in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.  LeeAnn and I wish you and your family a very happy and healthy 2017, and may God Bless you and your loved ones.

Last night, I voted against a change to the rules of the House of Representatives that will place the Office of Congressional Ethics under the jurisdiction of the House Ethics Committee. While I certainly understand the importance of due process, I believe this change is a mistake. It is critically important that all public servants – across the public spectrum – are held to the highest ethical standards.

I am extremely humbled and honored to have been chosen by the hardworking people of Eastern and Southeastern Ohio to serve them in the United States House of Representatives.  The 115th Congress has a historic opportunity to lead and make positive, lasting changes for the American people. It won’t be easy – it never is – but I am committed to the hard work of governing that lies ahead.  It matters little to me whether an idea originated with the Republicans or Democrats; rather, what matters is the impact it will have on those I represent – YOU.    Remember, I work for you – it’s not the other way around. Just as when I was first elected, I will decline the congressional health care plan and pension – as a 26-year Air Force veteran, my family and I will use the same healthcare that our nation’s veterans get – and, I still sleep in my office and return home each weekend; I am a proud resident of Marietta, Ohio, not the Washington D.C. Beltway.   Now, let’s get to work!

ObamaCare is collapsing under its own weight. In a meeting of Congressional Democrats on Wednesday, President Obama said he hasn’t done a good enough job communicating the benefits of his health law, which is why he thinks it is unpopular. I think he has communicated the ins and outs of the law just fine – people just don’t like it and know that it hasn’t lived up to its grand promises. Under Obamacare, healthcare premiums and deductibles are soaring, patient choices are dwindling, healthcare insurance markets are collapsing, and jobs and hours are being cut.  Making excuses like the President is doing is not honestly addressing the law’s failures.   According to a Gallup survey from November, a large majority of Americans want the law either significantly changed or replaced.  House Republicans are working with the Incoming Trump administration on a strategy to do just that.  Yesterday morning we met with the incoming Vice President, Mike Pence, on this topic and many others.

Yesterday, the House passed two important pieces of legislation designed to reclaim the "power of the purse" authority for Congress, and protect the American people from a last-minute regulatory onslaught - the Midnight Rules Relief Act of 2017, and the Regulations from the Executive In Need of Scrutiny (REINS) Act of 2017.  I voted YES for both bills.   By passing the Midnight Rules Relief Act (H.R. 21), the House acted to stop the Obama Administration from enacting more radical regulations that would cost the American people billions, and harm families and small businesses, as the moving trucks sit outside the White House.    The REINS Act (H.R. 26) would stop unelected bureaucrats in Washington from implementing job-killing regulations by requiring that Congress must approve any major regulations before they go into effect. The REINS Act would restore the checks and balances, and bring accountability to elected officials.  Remember, if you don't like what your senator or representative has done, you can vote them out of office. But, you can't vote a D.C. bureaucrat out of office.  That's what we're trying to fix.

Best of luck to the Youngstown State University Penguins as they play James Madison for the NCAA Football Championship Subdivision (FCS) National Championship today at noon in Frisco, Texas. A win would give the school its 5th national football title.  The Mahoning Valley is pulling for you!

Last week, I joined my colleagues on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives to read the Constitution to mark the beginning of the 115th Congress.  Now is as appropriate a time as ever to revisit the genius of our Founding Fathers who created the most powerful nation on earth by limiting the federal government’s power and protecting our individual freedoms, given to us by our Creator.   America’s greatness is derived from our citizens freedom to pursue their dreams and ambitions on their own terms, not a federal government that makes realizing those dreams more difficult.      When I travel around Eastern and Southeastern Ohio, I carry a copy of the Constitution with me in my jacket pocket. If you see me out and about, I'm happy to show it to you.

Today is National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day. Few professions, other than law enforcement, demand the willingness to sacrifice one’s own life in order to protect the safety and security of others. At a time when there is unrest -- and an increase in violence – directed toward police officers, let’s take a moment to reflect on how their service and sacrifice impact our own lives.  Police officers often work along the jagged line between civilized society and depravity, between order and chaos, protecting us from those who wish to inflict harm on innocent citizens.  It’s a dangerous, difficult, and oftentimes thankless job. America is a nation governed by the rule of law, and it is critically important that those enforcing our laws are respected.  I’ve had the privilege of meeting many brave law enforcement professionals up and down Eastern and Southeastern Ohio. Please join me today in thanking them for their service.

You may have heard about a controversial painting that is hanging in the U.S. Capitol.  The painting, submitted as part of the annual Congressional Art Competition, depicts police officers as pigs. It is disgusting and has no business hanging in the halls of Congress…it’s actually displayed just a few feet away from where police officers stand to keep those going in and out of the Capitol safe.  I offered some more thoughts in a video I recorded this afternoon:

Yesterday, the House passed legislation designed to spur American innovation. Washington red tape shouldn’t stand in the way of the next great startup company; the federal government should support innovation…not discourage and suppress it! One example is H.R. 79, the HALOS Act. This important legislation would allow “angel investors” to play a larger role in funding startups with more early capital so these new businesses can keep their heads above water and grow.   The House also approved legislation to increase broadband access (especially important in parts of Eastern and Southeastern Ohio), expand STEM education for women, and modernize government technology.

We’ve heard a lot about "fake news" recently. The latest example is an unverified and inflammatory report on President-elect Trump’s relationship with Russia published by an online, left-wing clickbait site. It’s a prime example of “fake news.”   One of the major reasons that Donald Trump was elected is that the American people are tired of media bias and character assassination by some in the national media.

Jobs in the American aluminum industry are important to our economy. Yet, China has subsidized certain producers of primary aluminum for years, creating an unfair advantage in the global market and driving aluminum prices down.   Therefore, we must ensure that an oversupply of Chinese aluminum does not negatively impact American workers. I am encouraged by the trade enforcement action that the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) took yesterday against China at the World Trade Organization (WTO).

ObamaCare has failed the American people; it is broken, and must be repealed and replaced. The American people deserve better and Republicans in Congress have been given a clear mandate to make that happen.  The only avenue to repeal ObamaCare is through the budget reconciliation process. Today’s budget resolution triggers the mechanism for using that process.  It’s important that we do this the right way – not through a 2,000 page bill, negotiated in a shady, backroom deal, and presented at midnight with a vote no more than two hours later. This process will be open, transparent, and visible to everyone.  It is critically important that the repeal and replacement of ObamaCare be done thoughtfully and carefully, as it will impact millions. The American people deserve a patient-centered health care system that offers more choices, better access, higher quality, and lower costs.  We must follow up the repeal with a suitable replacement; but, the current law cannot be undone without a transition period, because those currently on ObamaCare should not be subjected to unintended consequences.  This budget resolution I voted for today essentially fires the starting pistol to begin the process of repealing and replacing ObamaCare.  We’ve attempted to reverse this terrible law over fifty times during the past six years; now it’s actually going to happen.

On August 28, 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. stood on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial and delivered his famous “I Have a Dream Speech.”  It was in this speech that Dr. King called for all people to be united in justice, peace, and compassion, and to serve others.   Today we celebrate the life of Dr. King, one of America’s greatest champions of racial justice and equality; a man that delivered words of hope for all people, no matter the color of their skin. His leadership and commitment to fight for the freedom of all Americans continue to live on; they are testaments to the strength of his message.

I find it disgraceful that President Obama decided to commute the sentence of Army private Chelsea (formerly Bradley) Manning.  Manning released sensitive Army documents that contained names, sources, methods, and ongoing operational information to Wikileaks. U.S. interests abroad were harmed, covers were blown, careers were endangered and ended, and operations were compromised.  In the military, that’s called treason. As a 26-year career military officer, a veteran, and as an American citizen, I don’t understand the rationale for granting special treatment to Private Manning – someone who endangered the lives of fellow troops, intelligence officers, many of our allies, and our country.

I disagree with President Obama politically on far more than I agree with him on. But, it never even occurred to me to skip his Inauguration in 2013. Being in attendance for such a historic event was an honor, even though my preferred candidate came up short in the election.   One of the hallmarks of our republic is the peaceful transfer of power every 4 or 8 years. It's a shame that so many House Democrats (around 60 as of now) say they will not bear witness to this historic event; instead, they will effectively take their ball and go home. We're better than this, and we should start acting like it.

I visited Wheelersburg Elementary Tuesday morning to learn more about the school’s partnership with RSVP (the Retired Senior Volunteer Program), and to see how their reading program works. RSVP is a program specifically designed for seniors over the age of 55, with a wide variety of volunteer positions available. At the school, I observed the mentoring process, and  visited with the mentors and students to hear firsthand how this program has helped them. The staff and students had very high praise for the many volunteers.   There are currently 13 RSVP volunteers at the school who served 882 hours between September and December of 2016 – working with a total of 50 students.  I had a great time reading with the kids.
My message on Inauguration morning:

I had a great visit and tour of the Speyside Bourbon Cooperage in Jackson last week. The plant opened last year and is currently producing around 600 oak bourbon barrels per day, with a goal of getting that number up around 800 – all while employing local workers.  Speyside is working with a group of dedicated local officials who are determined to bring jobs and opportunities to the region. You can read more about my visit here:

This week is National #SchoolChoice Week.  I strongly believe that parents should be able to choose which schools are best for their children. These choices include traditional public schools, public charter schools, magnet schools, private schools, homeschooling, and online learning. Every student has different needs, every child learns differently, and every student deserves the opportunity to prosper – regardless of their zip code or other circumstances outside of their control. Empowering more families to choose the right education path for them and their children leads to more students succeeding.

Finally! The Keystone pipeline is getting new life.  It has strong bipartisan support in Congress, is supported by labor unions, small business owners, and the majority of the American people. One environmental impact study after another determined that construction of the pipeline poses little risk to the environment. By President Trump advancing this project, America will be one step closer to energy independence and create thousands of direct and indirect jobs.

Today, the House voted to protect the life of the unborn by passing the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act (H.R. 7), which bars taxpayer money from being spent to fund abortions. I co-sponsored, and voted in favor of this important bill. This vote, coupled with President Trump’s action yesterday – reinstituting the Mexico City policy that prohibits American tax dollars from going to organizations in foreign countries that provide abortions – will insure that American taxpayers will no longer foot the bill for abortions at home or abroad.    I strongly oppose even one cent of taxpayer dollars going toward abortion funding. As father of four and grandfather of six, and a member of the House Pro-Life Caucus, I will always fight for the rights of the unborn.

"Sanctuary cities” -- those cities that choose to not enforce federal immigration laws -- should not receive federal grant funding. To me, that is common sense. America is a nation of laws, and local jurisdictions should not be permitted to pick and choose which federal laws they enforce and which they do not; mayors and local governments are not above the law. The move today by the President, to deny funding to "sanctuary cities", is long overdue.

It was truly a privilege to hear British Prime Minister deliver an eloquent speech this afternoon. She said "we have the opportunity - indeed the responsibility - to renew [our] special relationship for this new age."  I certainly agree. Prime Minister May later added, "we [Great Britain] have chosen a different future ... that sees us take back control of the things that matter to us." That could be said for the American people here as well.   I am glad that our new President placed the bust of Winston Churchill back in the Oval Office, to signify the strong bond between the United States and the British people.
Welcome to all those in Washington for today's March for Life!

I support President Trump’s temporary, three month, precautionary action directed towards a handful of countries with a history of producing and exporting terrorists.  These countries are either torn apart by violence, or under the control of hostile, jihadist governments.  The United States Government has a responsibility to carefully vet those entering our country. Period.  This is not a “Muslim ban."  Many countries with majority Muslim populations, such as Indonesia, Egypt, Jordan, and Turkey were not included. The countries on this Trump Administration temporary ban list were previously designated by the Obama Administration, after Congress passed the Visa Waiver Program Improvement and Terrorist Travel Prevention Act, as nations where terrorism has flourished.  We remain a nation that welcomes immigrants with open arms, but our government owes the American people safety and security; and that requires prudent polices conceived from facts and reality, not polices driven by political correctness.

Today, I introduced a resolution, using the Congressional Review Act, that will protect American coal jobs by repealing the centerpiece of President Obama’s “War on Coal”, the so-called “Stream Protection Rule”.  This devastating rule, finalized in the waning days of the Obama Administration well after hardworking Americans sent a clear message to Washington that more regulation isn’t the answer, is jeopardizing thousands of coal and coal-related jobs, and entire coal communities, by placing a majority of America’s coal reserves off limits.   My legislation is expected to be considered by the full House this Wednesday.  An identical resolution has been introduced in the U.S. Senate by Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and once both chambers of Congress pass this resolution, it will go to President Trump’s desk for his signature, killing off this devastating anti-coal regulation once and for all.
MMMmmm...starting the day off right with a great cup of Silver Bridge coffee, Ohio coffee made right here in Gallia county.

I applaud President Trump’s nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the United States Supreme Court. Judge Gorsuch has an excellent constitutional background, and was confirmed without any opposition to a seat on the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals in 2006. Few judges in the United States are as qualified as Judge Gorsuch to serve on the Supreme Court and occupy the seat once held by Justice Scalia. I hope the Senate quickly approves this nomination.

Thanks to the folks with Habitat for Humanity for stopping by today to share some of what they have been doing recently. Keep up the excellent, important work you are doing. Those that volunteer their time with this organization are an inspiration to me…they do so much good for so many who need a little extra help.

A couple of days ago, I told you that I introduced H.J. Resolution 38, overturning the Interior Department's coal job-killing “Stream Protection Rule.” This afternoon, it passed the House by a vote of 228-194, with bipartisan support.   It is clear that the poorly named “Stream Protection Rule” was not designed to protect streams. If it was really about protecting our water, I wouldn’t have had an issue with it. It was really nothing more than a smokescreen to regulate the coal mining industry out of business, through overly burdensome regulations. With the help of House Leadership, we did our part to ensure this rule will never go into effect. As a result of my legislation, thousands of coal jobs throughout America will be saved. It will pass the Senate soon, and will then be signed by the President.   The action taken by the House today sends a strong message. Over 33,000 Ohioans are employed directly by the coal industry, and their hard work provides nearly 60% of our state’s energy. Today, the House stood firmly for them.
Strange claim. I have never heard this one before.  Makes no sense to me.

Earlier this week, I joined a bipartisan coalition of over 70 members of the House of Representatives in sending a letter to President Donald Trump urging him to include investments in rural broadband connectivity in his forthcoming infrastructure plans. I’ve said it here before, and I’ll say it again: the importance of broadband connectivity in attracting jobs and retaining businesses cannot be overstated. If you don’t have high-speed internet connectivity in your community, it is a serious disadvantage in business development, education, and emergency communications. High speed internet access is no longer a “pie in the sky” luxury; rather, it is essential for everyday activities. It is estimated that around 15% of Ohio’s rural population still lacks access to high-speed Internet that meets what the FCC considers as “adequate.” This must change.   You can read the full letter at the link below: http://welch.house.gov/sites/welch.house.gov/files/Telecom%202017.01.30%20Letter%20to%20Pres%20Trump%20re.%20broadband_0.pdf

Today we celebrate President Ronald Reagan's birthday, born 106 years ago in Tampico, Illinois. President Reagan taught us about leadership, and lessons about faith, freedom, liberty, and a strong, prosperous America. My favorite Reagan quote is: "It Can Be Done!", which is proudly displayed on my desk. President Reagan believed the best about the American people, and inspired us to listen to our best among us.  Like many Americans, I look back on his years in office fondly...he was uniquely and unfailingly optimistic -- whether staring down the Soviet Union during the Cold War, or dealing with former Speaker of the House Tip O'Neill and the Democratic party to adopt his economic agenda.  President Reagan was a giant among world leaders, and was one of our greatest presidents.  He reminded us often that America's greatest days are yet to come...I still believe that.

I always enjoy sitting down with leaders from the Ohio National Guard. Major General Mark Bartman, the Adjutant General for Ohio, and members of his team stopped by my office yesterday to provide an update on the status of their forces, upcoming deployments, and critical infrastructure improvements they are working on. Thanks for all you do for our great state and the United States as a whole.

‎I was asked to be on MSNBC's "Hardball" earlier this week. The segment was about President Trump's immigration executive order -- an order that I support. Chris Matthews let both sides state their case which provided clear contrasts for the viewer. Reasonable people can disagree on policy, but it's important to have a calm, fact-based discussion.  And, that's what we had.  In this case, I was encouraged that even left-leaning journalist Chris Matthews agrees that it is constitutionally mandated that the President has the sole responsibility to make judgments about such decisions as immigration when it comes to keeping Americans safe...not federal judges.

Last week, the Republican Israel Caucus met with Israel's Ambassador to the United States, Ron Dermer. It was a great meeting, and we had a good discussion about Israel's priorities.  I also led over 40 of my colleagues in sending a letter to President Trump last week to lay the groundwork to help the incoming administration mend America's relationship with Israel after the setbacks we've had over the last eight years. This is especially important in light of the recent anti-Israel action (or lack thereof) taken by the Obama administration at the United Nations - which did not represent the will of the American people or Congress. It's important that President Trump knows that he has allies in Congress that are ready to work with him on this important national security issue - for America and for Israel.

Yesterday, I supported H.R. 974 – the BRAVE Act – which would allow the Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, when awarding procurement contracts for goods or services, to give preference to contractors that employ veterans on a full-time basis. The bill would cost taxpayers nothing, but it would reward companies that seek out and invest in our nation's heroes.  Importantly, the legislation allows the Secretary of the VA to debar contractors who purposely misrepresent their employment of veterans in order to receive a contract.

Good to meet with retired mine workers who made the trip out from Ohio. Among other issues, we discussed their support for H.R. 179 – the Miners Protection Act of 2017. I am a co-sponsor of this important legislation, because it is imperative that the benefits these hardworking men and women earned through decades of dangerous, difficult work are protected.

Recently, I sat down with students from Ohio University’s Heritage College of Osteopathic Medicine, who were in Washington for the National Rural Health Association conference. We discussed ways to strengthen healthcare and increase access in rural areas, and these young people talked at length about many of their ideas to improve care to those they will serve.   As you know, I strongly believe in telehealth medicine…in more rural areas, telehealth capabilities can increase access to quality healthcare and lower costs for patients who might not otherwise have access to it, or might not have the ability to travel long distances to see specialists. Telehealth alone isn’t the answer, but it can be a big step forward in providing access to quality, affordable healthcare for millions of Americans in rural areas.

I was at the White House today as President Trump signed my resolution to protect coal jobs and coal families.  During his campaign, the President made a promise to coal country, and today he began fulfilling that promise. Working together, we protected coal jobs by preventing a last-minute, Obama-era rule from taking effect. The rule would have made it so costly to mine coal; in fact, the industry would have been regulated straight out of business. On behalf of coal families in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio, and across the country, thank you President Trump.   This is the eighth piece of legislation I’ve authored, including seven during the previous administration, that has been signed into law.

Members of my district staff are volunteering today at the Chillicothe VA Medical Center, preparing and serving lunch to local veterans and their loved ones. The Chillicothe facility serves many veterans who reside in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio…I’ve been impressed with the medical staff and employees there, and, as a veteran, making sure those who served our nation are treated with the respect they’ve earned will always remain a top priority of mine.

Today is commonly known as “Presidents Day,” though it is officially the federal holiday, commemorating George Washington’s Birthday.  Without George Washington, there would be no Declaration of Independence, no Constitution, and no United States of America.  Not only was he elected unanimously once, it happened again when he ran for reelection.  That is unimaginable in today's politics.  The Constitution created the office of the President, but it was George Washington that created the presidency.  Of course, in addition to being our first President, Washington led the Continental Army to victory against Great Britain, the most powerful military in the world at the time. He also created the first military badge of merit for the common soldier. Revived on his 200th birthday, the Purple Heart is awarded to soldiers injured in battle. It seems about the only thing George Washington didn’t do was chop down that cherry tree.  After helping to found our nation, George Washington could have become king, but chose not to, saying "I didn't fight (King) George III to become (King) George I."   There were many giants among our nation’s founders, but few could argue that Washington was THE giant among giants.  In fact, it was his leadership that was most responsible for the successful implementation of our radically new form of democratic government – a constitutionally-based representative republic.

This afternoon, I participated in an education and career development focused town-hall with a group of  young people enrolled in the “Career Exploration and Readiness Program” at Zane State College – Cambridge Campus. The class is open to Guernsey County residents aged 18-24 who face barriers to employment. I talked a little bit about my background, and how I was in a similar position to many of them before I entered the U.S. Air Force after high school. If I made it to the halls of Congress, they certainly have the ability – with wise decision making now – to achieve what they set out to accomplish. Afterwards, I took questions on many different topics.  Thanks to Zane State for the invitation to speak!

After meeting with various small businesses and individuals today talking about jobs and shale development, I met with members of the Plumbers and Pipefitters Local 495 in Cambridge. I meet with labor groups up and down Eastern and Southeastern Ohio on a regular basis.  Ensuring our workforce is trained and ready to go isn’t a partisan issue – it’s a jobs issue.

Today I was in Vinton, in Gallia County, to visit the Field of Hope Community Campus – a 46 acre campus treating those struggling with addiction, and a training center to help them restart their lives. Approximately 40 people attended our session today, as we discussed the opioid addiction epidemic that is sweeping across our nation. The goal at the faith-based, non-profit Field of Hope is to breathe new life into the community, and to assist area families ravaged by poverty, drug and substance abuse, and more.  I assisted Field of Hope in their efforts to obtain grants to help with their sewer system and facilities. Thankfully, they were able to secure a few of them, which they matched with their donated work and private funds to help get things going. The campus is an old high school, which needed a lot of work when it was acquired…and, volunteers are putting a lot of sweat equity and prayer into it. It’s paying off.   I heard some incredibly powerful and touching stories today. I even shared my own personal story of my father whose life was plagued by addiction. The Field of Hope is a blessing to many who live in Gallia County and the surrounding area.  It was great to be there, and I plan to return when they finish the many construction projects underway.

Yesterday, I toured the oldest remaining original courthouse in Chester, Ohio with a group of volunteers who run the museum.  It is actually the oldest standing courthouse in the Northwest Territory.  Thanks to Mary Powell, the director of the museum, and the active members of the Meigs County Historical Society for all the work they do preserving history for future generations. Meigs County has a lot to be proud of!

I thoroughly enjoyed talking with so many veterans over lunch today at the VFW hall in Cambridge. We talked about many issues, including wait times for vets to be seen by a doctor, the inconveniences of vets having to travel long distances to see a healthcare provider, much needed reforms at the VA, and others.  The House and Senate Veterans Affairs Committees are holding hearings next week during which several veterans services organizations (VSOs) will be providing Congress with their legislative priorities over the next two years as well as giving their ideas as to how best to reform the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to improve its services. I'll be taking the feedback and ideas I heard today to House VA Chairman Dr. Phil Roe for his consideration as the committee begins this important work.  We owe our veterans a great deal of thanks -- and it doesn't have to be Veterans Day to pay tribute to those who served. It's neither the press, nor those who speak the loudest that we have to thank for our freedoms - like our freedom of speech.  Rather, it's America's veterans who risked their lives to protect and defend us that we need to thank - every day.
Looking forward to tonight's address...what do you want to hear from President Trump?

The most unconventional President in modern times gave the most uplifting and uniting speech heard in the House Chamber in at least a decade.  Importantly, he didn’t divide us by group…the President spoke to us as one people - as Americans.  It was refreshing to hear the President speak so passionately, and so gratefully, in praise of those who risk their lives each day to protect us…America’s heroes – our law enforcement, our military, and our veterans.   And, he gave a message of hope to the hardworking people of America, especially Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.

On August 7, 1953, President Eisenhower signed a congressional joint resolution that officially declared March 1, 1803 the date of Ohio’s admittance into the Union.   “Whereas, in pursuance of an act of Congress, passed on the thirtieth day of April, one thousand eight hundred and two, entitled an Act to enable the people of the Eastern division of the territory northwest of the river Ohio to form a constitution and state government, and for the admission of such state into the Union, on an equal footing with the original States, and for other purposes.”   We have come a long way since Ohio’s admittance into the Union, and we have many things and people to be proud of - the Wright Brothers, John Glenn, Neil Armstrong, the first oil well on the North American Continent.  I am honored to serve the hard working people of Eastern and Southeastern Ohio, and I’m optimistic about the year ahead.   Join me in wishing the Buckeye State a Happy 214th Birthday!

As you know, substance abuse is a growing problem in far too many communities across the country. And, Eastern and Southeastern Ohio is no exception. This week, along with my Democrat colleague Doris Matsui of California, I reintroduced legislation to reduce teen abuse of over-the-counter cough medicines. Every year, millions of Americans use over-the-counter cough and cold medications containing dextromethorphan (DXM). Though the vast majority of us use these medications to alleviate the common cold, some young people are abusing medications containing DXM. In fact, about 1 in 30 kids intentionally misuses over-the-counter cough medicine. Many kids - mistakenly - think that if it’s an over-the-counter medicine it can’t hurt them. Unfortunately, they are wrong…and many parents aren’t even aware this is an issue.   Passing this bipartisan legislation would be an important first-step in stemming the tide of drug addiction - for kids, families, and our communities.

Today, I was in Mahoning County for a variety of meetings, including a tour of the Loghurst Farm Museum. The home was built in 1805, and is thought to be the oldest remaining log home in the Western Reserve. In fact, between 1835-1845, Loghurst served as a stop on the Underground Railroad, helping provide safe passage for slaves fleeing the South. The property is now part of the Western Reserve Historical Society, though it is maintained by the Canfield Heritage Foundation.   It’s a great piece of preserved Ohio history, on a well-traveled section of Route 224 right here in Canfield. You may have driven by it many times without knowing the history of the property. It’s definitely worth checking out!

Earlier this morning I stopped at the Washington County Veterans Service Office (VSO) in Marietta. It’s always good to hear directly from those on the front lines who deal with the bureaucracy at the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) on a daily basis.  I read an article in the Marietta Times last month about how busy they’ve been lately, so I wanted to stop by and hear from the full-time staff there. We talked about how we need to speed up the process for veterans to receive their records from the National Personnel Records Center.  And, I asked them if they had any other issues I could take to Washington on behalf of the veterans we serve.   In addition to assisting veterans with preparing, filing, and following-up with their VA claims, about a third of the services the Washington Co. VSO provides are transportation related. Keep up your good work for our veterans…it is not going unnoticed.

Earlier today I met with Mark Hunter from Scioto County. His Steve A. Hunter Hope Fund provides weekend "backpack" food for over 1,000 students in 20 elementary schools in Scioto, Pike, & Adams Counties. He stopped by the office to talk – he’s in Washington for the National Anti-Hunger Policy Conference.   People like Mark oftentimes do important, generous work like this that goes unnoticed. So, thank you, Mark, for your commitment to service and the sacrifices you make to provide nutritious meals to children in need.

We are just at the beginning of the process to repeal and replace ObamaCare, but my initial thoughts about the America Health Care Act are positive. ObamaCare is rapidly collapsing under its own weight, and something must be done. This legislation would continue to protect patients with pre-existing conditions, remove Obamacare’s onerous taxes and mandates, provide a stable transition from the current system, and importantly, return much of America's healthcare policy decision-making, including Medicaid, to the states by providing them with the flexibility to effectively meet their population’s unique needs, particularly those families struggling to make ends meet.    I look forward to continuing to advance policies that will lower health care costs, empower patients, and increase access to care.

Just crossed the 24 hour point in this marathon legislative hearing to advance legislation to Repeal and Replace Obamacare.  It was a long day yesterday, and a long night last night...and, we still have more work to do.  But, it is critically important that we complete this task, because Obamacare is collapsing of its own weight. We owe it to the American people to return healthcare decisions to doctors and patients, and provide ALL Americans more choices and access to affordable, quality healthcare.  Working for you!

This morning’s jobs report, showing a gain of 235,000 added jobs, confirms the surge of optimism that consumers and businesses are feeling with the start of the new administration. It’s a great sign that construction jobs are leading the way, growing by 58,000 jobs – the most in over a decade - along with the manufacturing sector adding 28,000 new jobs. Two energy sectors very important to Eastern and Southeastern Ohio also posted gains: Those employed in the oil and gas industry climbed by 1,800, and coal mining jobs rose by 300.    This is a very encouraging report for American workers.
Great to meet and speak with students from Jefferson County who were in DC this past week as part of the Close Up program!

Earlier this year, veteran Joe Brown of Wellsville had the medals he earned from his service in Vietnam stolen from his home. I saw a clip of his story on the local news, and it made me furious.  Working with the National Personnel Records Center, I arranged for Mr. Brown to receive replacement medals.    This morning, I had the honor of presenting Joe with the Purple Heart, Army Air Medal, Army Commendation Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Vietnam Service Medal, Combat Infantryman Badge, and Republic of Vietnam Campaign Ribbon, in addition to the Marksman Badge and Auto Rifle, Machine Gun, and Rifle Bars. Another medal -- a Silver Star -- that Joe also earned is on its way.    I hope his original medals are found…but if not, Joe at least deserves these replacements. These awards aren’t just pieces of medal and plastic to Joe – they are part of his life and those he served with.

Yesterday, I stopped at Bridgeport H.S. to speak with the junior and senior classes.  Many of them are in life situations similar to where I was at their age, not knowing what they wanted to do next. I talked about how college is a good option, but also that there are other, good paying job opportunities in manufacturing, coal, and the oil and gas industry here along the Ohio River. And, in addition to traditional four-year colleges, there are education opportunities to pursue a skilled trade in  technical schools, community colleges, and the military.     The students asked GREAT questions yesterday…some of the most thoughtful questions I’ve ever been asked at a school – or anywhere. They asked about topics such as the impact of social media on America's culture and politics, immigration policy, education, job creation, how we handle welfare, healthcare reform, and others. Speaking with students like these always give me optimism for America's future. Thanks for having me.

Today I was privileged to meet and speak to Ohio pastors in town with Awake America. This week is the non-profit group’s 5th annual Capitol Connection gathering. Their effort is not about political positions or parties;  rather it’s about people of faith connecting with those serving in government. I discussed the importance of Americans putting country before politics, and remaining patient as Congress works towards enacting solutions to our nation’s most pressing challenges. Thank you to Pastor Wolvin for inviting me to spend time with Awake America - Ohio.

Yesterday I met with Ohio Farm Bureau (OFB) county presidents from Gallia, Athens/Meigs, Monroe, Jackson/Vinton, Guernsey, Muskingum, Tuscarawas, Harrison, Jefferson, Columbiana, and Mahoning counties. It was the group’s 71st annual trip to Washington! We discussed many relevant issues facing Ohio agriculture including trade, regulatory reform, and the farm bill. OFB is a grassroots membership organization that supports Ohio’s very important food and farm community. Thanks for visiting today - please keep up your hard work on behalf of Ohio’s farm families.

America is over $20 trillion in debt – an absolutely staggering amount. We can’t keep spending money we don’t have. President Trump said this during the campaign, and his budget submission today reflects that. There is no question the federal government can, and must, be better stewards of taxpayer dollars -- it's your money, not Washington's money. It is possible to grow our economy, create jobs, and provide for national security all while shrinking the size of our federal government and our national debt.  A serious debate about the need and effectiveness of many federal programs is long overdue.

This past week, I voted YES on H.R. 1259 -- the VA Accountability First Act. The bill, which passed with bipartisan support, would reform the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), and improve the care our nation's heroes receive by giving the VA Secretary increased flexibility to remove, demote, or suspend any VA employee for poor performance or misconduct. Despite the outrageous transgressions by a few employees at the VA, it can still take several months - or even more than a year - to remove a permanent VA employee.  That is ridiculous. Importantly, this legislation keeps in place important whistleblower protections to prevent retaliation against employees who sound the alarm.

The gym was full on Saturday night at Warren High School, as the school's members of the FFA were celebrated at their 57th Annual Banquet. As someone who grew up on a farm, I was extremely proud to hear about all of this chapter's accomplishments last year. I was pleased to be asked to say a few words, and I tried to impress upon the young people in attendance that they are America's future leaders.  I look forward to hearing about all of your successes in the years to come!

Happy National Ag Day! I’m grateful for all of the Ohio farmers who help feed families around the world, especially here at home in America.  You play a key role in our dominance in the world economy. #nationalagday #agday

The Fairland Dragons are off to the Boys Basketball State Tournament in Columbus. It’s the first time since 1961 the school has made the Ohio Final Four.  With a 24-1 record, and no seniors on the team, this is already a season to remember. All of Proctorville is proud of your efforts…and I join them in wishing you the best on Friday!
Thank you President Trump for approving the Keystone XL pipeline - creating thousands of construction jobs for American workers!

I am deeply disappointed that the House was unable to move forward with today’s vote on this important legislation that would have repealed and replaced ObamaCare. I voted for this legislation in two committees, and would have supported the bill had it come up for a vote today.  I believe the House missed an historic opportunity to reverse the pain that Obamacare has inflicted on the American people, and prevent the pain that millions of Americans are likely to feel as that onerous law continues to unravel.

There was a huge turnout today in Scioto County for the March Against Heroin, created to raise awareness about this growing epidemic. When asked to speak by the organizers, I knew immediately what I was going to talk about -- how addiction affected my family growing up, and how devastating it can be.  As I’ve said many times before, this is not a political issue – addiction doesn’t discriminate. I hear about the opioid and heroin addiction problem often as I travel up and down Eastern and Southeastern Ohio, and I’ll continue to work to address this growing crisis. But, lawmakers in Washington, Columbus or elsewhere cannot solve this problem alone. Communities, families, churches, law enforcement, the courts, and elected  officials at all levels - especially groups like we saw today - must come together to stop the problem.

I was pleased to be asked to join President Trump as he signed an energy independence executive order. His actions reversed many of the efforts by the previous administration to kill fossil fuel-related jobs across Ohio and the United States. There is no reason to punish consumers and job creators for responsibly using our natural energy resources, and the action today will allow American companies and workers to compete – and succeed – on a level playing field in the global economy.   Today, the President demonstrated that there can be common-sense balance – it is possible to have environmentally responsible regulations that don’t result in lost jobs and skyrocketing electricity costs.

Today is Vietnam Veterans Day. On this day in 1973, America’s intervention in Vietnam ended. Our veterans answered their country’s call, and they served with distinction and honor. Over 58,000 American men and women never made it home from that bloody conflict. And, sadly, many of those who did come home received protests and ridicule from their own countrymen. Virtually everyone from my generation knew someone who made the ultimate sacrifice in Vietnam.   The Vietnam War Veterans Recognition Act of 2017 passed the House and Senate this year, and was signed into law yesterday. We have not forgotten – and will not forget – the over nine million Americans who served with honor in Vietnam. You answered the call to serve, like so many other patriots have done throughout our nation's history. Thank you for your service.

President Trump made a promise to the American people during his campaign: he promised to take action to keep drugs from pouring into our country and to help those who have been affected by them. Today, along with other members of Congress, I met with President Trump at the White House where he expanded on his commitment to confront this important challenge. He again expressed his willingness to work with anyone, from inside or outside of government, and from any political background, to find solutions to protect Americans from this dangerous epidemic.  Ohio – particularly Eastern and Southeastern Ohio -- has been hit particularly hard by the opioid crisis; there isn’t a day that goes by that I don’t hear or read another heartbreaking story. I look forward to continuing to work with the President and other leaders as we fight this scourge.   As I have stated many times, and as I told the President today, this issue is not a political one…it is an American issue. Addiction does not discriminate by age, race, social class, economic status, or political party.  Solving this problem is going to take communities, families, churches, and elected officials from the President all the way down to township trustees. We all must be in this fight together.

The 2-174th Air Defense Artillery regiment is deploying to Iraq and Afghanistan. Their mission is to provide counter rocket artillery and mortar operations.  295 soldiers are deploying; 63 for whom this will be their 3rd or more deployment.  Many of these heroes are your friends and neighbors from right here in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.  After today's Call to Duty ceremony in McConnelsville, these members of the Ohio National Guard departed, and are now on their way to a pre-mobilization training site, where they will finalize preparations before deployment.   God Bless the men and women and their families of the 2nd of the 174th.

I’ve received some questions on the elimination of the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) in President’s Trump budget, which was released last month.  From what I have seen so far, there is a lot to like in the President's budget. As I stated before, we are over $20 Trillion in national debt, and we need to have the long overdue debate about the need and effectiveness of many federal programs. However, cutting funding for the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) would not be one of the places to cut or eliminate. Since its creation in 1965, ARC helped to create hundreds of thousands of jobs, slashed the number of high-poverty counties in Appalachia, and helped to reduce the infant mortality rate drastically. ARC invests in activities that address their five goals: economic opportunities, ready workforce, critical infrastructure, natural and cultural assets, and leadership and community capacity.  There is no doubt the ARC is critically important to the people of Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.  I will continue to do everything I can to protect the ARC.

It was great visiting with the Ohio State Building & Construction Trades Council members at their breakfast this morning in Washington.  These highly skilled workers bring expertise to the table every day on the projects they work on across our state.   Republicans and Democrats have the opportunity to come together to produce an important  infrastructure bill – one that is badly needed. These pressing, much needed projects – upgrading roads, bridges, airports, and our broadband and energy infrastructure -- are big job and opportunity creators for our district. Many of those who I spoke with today, and many of the other labor groups I meet with regularly – which include our friends and neighbors - would be involved in these infrastructure rebuilding projects.

Nice to meet with representatives of the Ohio Fire Chiefs’ Association yesterday in my Washington office.  We discussed several important issues, such as the need for FIRE and SAFER grants, the public safety communications spectrum, and other legislation promoting public safety. Thanks for stopping by, but more importantly, thanks to you and your local departments for serving our communities.

Today, flags across the country are flying at half-staff honoring Ohio's own John Glenn, a spaceflight pioneer and American hero. Earlier today he was buried at Arlington National Cemetery where he'll rest among our nation's finest.

The images this week out of Syria were horrifying - dozens of men, women, and children were murdered. The use of chemical weapons is illegal under international law, and the use of them cannot be tolerated - anywhere! The Trump Administration is justified in these tactical strikes against the Assad regime - a designated state sponsor of terrorism - who has repeatedly demonstrated its willingness to commit barbaric acts against its own people.

Yesterday, Muskingum University officially welcomed Dr. Susan Hasseler as its 21st president. I was pleased to join the trustees, faculty, staff, alumni, and students in New Concord for the ceremony.  She spoke about the importance of investing in students to ensure they're prepared to succeed upon graduation. I met with Dr. Hasseler a few weeks ago, and I was very impressed. Muskingum University is in good hands. Muskingum University
Happy Passover to our Jewish friends in Ohio and around the world.

Last week, I reintroduced the BRICK Act, which stands for the Blocking Regulatory Interference from Closing Kilns Act. The vast majority of brick plants in the U.S. are small and/or family owned operations. But, to comply with existing EPA requirements, these small businesses will be forced to borrow millions for required control equipment – if they can even find someone to lend them the capital. The rule mandating this equipment is currently pending in the courts, so until judicial review is complete, this rule should not be implemented and businesses should be protected from its undue costs. We should be working to preserve this industry, not regulate it out of business!

Easter, the season during which we celebrate the crucifixion and resurrection of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, is a very important holiday for my family and me...I'm sure it is for many of you.  The Bible reminds us that Christ's sacrifice is the foundation of our Christian faith. Those who choose to accept Jesus as Savior, walk with him, and follow his example will receive eternal life.  His sacrifice and love offer humanity's only true hope.   This Easter, I pray that you are able to spend special time with your loved ones; and that we all will take time to reflect on the many blessings God has given to America.  May He protect all our men and women in uniform who have served or are serving far away from their families to defend our freedoms.  LeeAnn and I wish you all a very Happy Easter.

The annual Union Hospital Auxiliary Luncheon was held today in Dover. This year's check - for $253,147 - pushed the organization past the $4 million milestone for the amount of money raised since the Dover's hospital's inception in 1949. Keep up the great work on behalf of Tuscarawas County and the region!

It’s official – Tax Day is here. Hardworking American families and small businesses again this year will fork over more of their hard-earned money to a broken down and inefficient federal government. The document our Founding Fathers wrote that created the greatest nation on the planet - the U.S. Constitution - has less than 5,000 words. Compare that to the U.S. tax code, which is over 75,000 pages long. And, despite all the taxes you pay, the federal government still borrows over $1 trillion a year.  It’s depressing to think about.  It’s far past time for a fresh start…we need to start over and throw out our current tax code.  It has been more than thirty years since comprehensive tax reform was last enacted in Congress. The American people deserve a simpler, fairer, and flatter tax code that rewards success and encourages economic growth. This is one of the primary reasons I came to Congress in the first place...I'm looking forward to helping get it done. Now is the time for Congress to act.

It was great to again visit with all the great team at ThermoFisher Scientific's Marietta location this morning. ThermoFisher produces many highly technical products, including environmental products and controls, laboratory equipment for scientific research, incubators, and freezers. Each time I visit, I'm impressed by the innovative spirit of the workers there. After my tour, I spoke with, and took a few questions from, some of the 575 folks employed at this location.  Thanks for having me...I hope to visit again soon.

I stopped for some pizza...at McDonald's, of all places, in Pomeroy, Ohio! This is one of only two McDonalds in the country that still serve pizza. I had the Supreme, and it was pretty good! Tyler, a manager at this location, said that store sales have skyrocketed over the last couple months as word has gotten around about the pizza. The employees there were very friendly and professional...and, they are enjoying the notoriety.

Yesterday, I spoke with a group of students at Meigs High School (MHS). I told them that one of these days, and sooner than most of them think, they will be the next generation of America's leaders - it will be their turn to take the reigns of leadership of our great nation, but it's up to them to determine what kind of leaders they will be. I also took a few questions - I would have taken a few more, but I didn't want to be the one responsible for them missing lunch! The students at MHS are led by principal Travis Abbott, who returned this year to the district he graduated from in 1996. I know Travis from his previous position in Marietta, and his new group of students are lucky to have him at the helm of the school.   While I was there, I also met with sophomore Cole Durst. Cole received the highest score in the entire state in the American Legion's Americanism and Government Test program - over 55,000 students statewide took the test. Congratulations, Cole!  Great job...what an achievement!

It was a very exciting day for Madison Smith of Indian Creek High School in Wintersville, as she signed a letter of intent to compete on the track and field team at the United States Air Force Academy. I nominated her last December for an appointment as part of my Service Academy nomination process. I’m grateful I could be there today for her ceremony.  Good luck, Madison…I know you will represent us all very well!

Last week, I visited Thermo Fisher Scientific in Marietta; the company manufactures innovative laboratory equipment. I received an up-close look at some of their newer products and spoke and took questions from many of their employees. Manufacturers like Thermo Fisher provide a strong base of jobs and foster economic growth in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio. It’s critically important that we inform our middle and high school students about the opportunities available to them right here at home.    While there, I was presented with the National Association of Manufacturers’ (NAM) Award for Manufacturing Legislative Excellence. I’m proud to be associated with the outstanding work NAM is doing on behalf of companies in Ohio and across the country, and I look forward to continuing my legislative work to expand manufacturing opportunities. Congress must support policies that encourage job creation and economic growth, and eliminate burdensome regulations that make it difficult to do business.

Today, the Congressional Israel Victory Caucus launched, and I'm proud to be co-chairing it.  The caucus is chartered around one irrefutable principle - Israel has a right to exist as the Jewish state, and has right to defend herself.  The aim is to educate our colleagues about daily life in Israel, and the events that have led to the present day conflict situation. After 8 years of the Obama Administration creating uncertainty of America’s support for our closest ally in the Middle East, it is vitally important that Israel knows she has strong allies both in Congress and now, once again, in the White House.  Israel is America’s closest ally in the Middle East, and our ally has a right to exist - period. This is not negotiable - not  now, not ever.    I look forward to co-chairing this very important caucus with Congressman Ron DeSantis of Florida.

I met with some graduating seniors from Oak Hill High School this morning – they have only three weeks of school left.  They came to D.C. to see how our government works...glad they came, because they are our future leaders.  Have a memorable trip, and great graduation…and good luck in your future endeavors.

Small businesses are the economic heartbeat of cities, villages, and towns all across Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.  These businesses account for over 60% of the jobs in our country…and without them, America doesn’t work.   Our area has some of the best small businesses around. I caught up with two Air Force Academy Cadets last evening, Jeffrey McKnight from Bishop Rosecrans High School and Ethan Moore from Gallia Academy. These two were in a group of the Senior Cadets who are in Washington for an event at the White House to commemorate the US Air Force Academy’s winning of the Commander In Chief’s Trophy. I nominated Ethan to attend the Air Force Academy in 2013…and now he is a senior. Wow, time flies! It’s very gratifying to see so many young men and women who I previously nominated to a U.S. Service Academy thriving.

Community banks all over the country have been hit very hard by Washington regulations. We lose about one community financial institution every day – and that’s very troubling, especially in small, rural communities.   I recently cosponsored legislation (H.R. 1116, the TAILOR Act) that requires our federal financial regulatory agencies to take risk profiles and business models into account when taking regulatory action -- and the impact of applying such regulatory action to our credit unions and community banks. This legislation will save valuable time and resources, while fostering a regulatory environment where banks and credit unions can focus their time and assets on serving their clients and investing in their surrounding communities, rather than sinking their resources into complying with overly burdensome regulations.

When our Founding Fathers created the United States of America, they created a nation founded on the concept of freedom "OF" religion, not freedom "FROM" religion. Today, our National Day of Prayer, a tradition dating back to our first President, George Washington, is an important reminder of the critical role that faith played in our nation’s founding – and the role faith must continue to play if we are to continue to remain "...One Nation, Under God, With Liberty and Justice for All."

Today, the House of Representatives took a major step toward keeping our promise with the American people to repeal and replace Obamacare. We are here today because many Americans experienced the broken promises of Obamacare – they saw their premiums skyrocket, lost access to their doctors, and lost the health care plans that worked for them. As we speak, many states and counties are down to one health care provider. Obamacare premiums continue to rise, and costs are out-of-control.  The American Health Care Act (AHCA), which I voted in favor of, will maintain protections for people with pre-existing conditions, decrease the overall cost of health care coverage, and strengthen the health insurance market so that all Americans have more choices and greater access to affordable, quality healthcare. It’s a vast improvement over Obamacare that continues to unravel.  Read my full statement here:
My friend, colleague, and fellow veteran, Brian Mast - who gave more than most in service to our great country - spoke powerfully on the House Floor last week about many of Obamacare's failures.

Yesterday morning, I appeared on C-Span, broadcasting live from the Ohio (Coal) Transloading Center in Powhatan Point, right near the border of Belmont and Monroe Counties on Route 7. I spoke with the host and took calls about coal and other energy sources.
