I made many stops in Washington County today, including speaking with members of the Marietta Area Chamber of Commerce.   I provided an update about some of what has been taking place over the first half of the year in our nation’s capital that has an effect on Washington County and Mid-Ohio County businesses and citizens. After being all over Eastern and Southeastern Ohio this month, it was nice to spend part of my day right here at home at The Galley.   Our discussion focused a lot on tax reform and the federal budget – two critical issues we will focus on when I head back to Washington in early September.

Earlier this week, I was in Barnesville to meet with South Central Power co-op members and employees from Belmont, Monroe, Harrison, and Noble Counties. The Cooperative is a private enterprise owned and operated by the people it serves (in this case 110,000 residential, commercial, and industrial customers).  I provided the group a legislative update on issues that are important to their members - such as coal, current energy prices, liquid natural gas, and other topics  that impact electricity markets.  We also discussed ways in which the group could work with internet providers to increase much-needed broadband internet access to underserved areas here in our region.

I’ve been watching some of the coverage out of Southeastern Texas – the flooding and destruction are surreal. Houston is America’s 4th largest city, and it's hard to view the images coming across the news that show it predominately under water.  Local first responders and emergency managers seem to be doing a great job under very trying circumstances, and the volunteer effort under way is truly inspiring. The devastation brought by Hurricane Harvey illustrates that flood waters, rain, and natural disasters don’t discriminate.  All areas of Houston were hit…and people of all incomes, ethnicities, races, and social statuses have been affected - and they are coming together to help each other out.  This is the best of America emerging in the face of a tragic event...it proves what we are made of.  If there’s a silver lining in Hurricane Harvey's destruction, it’s seeing that there is still far more that unites us as Americans than divides us.   The American people are with the people affected in Texas. This storm caused and continues to cause historic damage...not something you can ever fully prepare for.  And, it looks like all levels of government are doing everything they can to assist those in need and to help minimize the human suffering.  Thankfully, the death toll is very low so far - let’s pray it stays that way.

Tax reform is one of the major issues that Congress MUST address when we head back to Washington next week.    We’re way past due for a fresh start as it relates to our tax code. It’s been over 30 years since comprehensive tax reform was last enacted by Congress and signed into law. You deserve a simpler, fairer, and flatter tax code – one that rewards success and encourages economic growth. I’m working hard to get real tax reform across the finish line. The op-ed below has more of my thoughts on this subject.

Last night, I spoke to members of the Ohio Valley Oil and Gas Association in St. Clairsville at their monthly meeting. We discussed federal energy policy – including changes made by the new administration, the work being done by the House Energy and Commerce Committee on pipeline permitting and critical infrastructure, an update on the current backlog at the Federal Energy Regulatory Committee (FERC), and the potential cracker plant in Belmont County. Following my remarks, I opened it up for questions. It was nice to see old friends and new faces.

Today I made a visit to Dogs 4 Warriors, located just outside Bowerston. This non-profit organization provides professionally trained service dogs at no cost to combat veterans suffering from PTSD and other combat related illnesses. It is managed by its founder, Shelia Slezak, who has been training dogs professionally for over 30 years.    Once a dog is accepted into Shelia’s program, they are then matched up with a veteran based on their specific needs. Each dog and veteran team receive training together for two weeks on site before the dog goes to its new home. The entire program is done at no cost to the veteran – the program is funded through donations and fundraisers - which is amazing considering many organizations charge up to $30,000 to purchase a service dog.    You often hear people say that they won’t forget the sacrifice of those who served. Shelia and the team at Dogs 4 Warriors certainly have not; in the last three-and-a-half years, 90 veterans in 27 states have been provided with service dogs.  All I can say is wow…keep up the great work. What an inspirational story right here in Eastern Ohio.

Yesterday, I stopped at Compco Quaker Manufacturing in Salem. Back in June, a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) was issued to employees of the then named Quaker Manufacturing that the company would likely be shutting down, putting 115 immediate jobs in jeopardy. Compco, also based in Columbiana County, came in and worked with the bank, Quaker Mfg. management, the receiver, and the company’s customers to quickly buy Quaker, preserving all the jobs. There were a lot of smiles as I toured and spoke with employees.    The employees and families of the new Compco Quaker Manufacturing should also know that their local leaders worked hard behind the scenes and did everything in their power to help keep this longtime Salem staple open for business. Under new ownership, the company is looking forward to the future and possible expansion.

Summer went by way too fast. Today, I am proud to join with all the hard-working taxpayers across Eastern and Southeastern Ohio as we celebrate Labor Day with our family and friends.  I’m hopeful that, today, every American will take the time to reflect on our nation’s remarkable story of innovation, ingenuity, and economic success. We're hard workers - that is our history - and, through our free enterprise, market driven system, our economy has created the highest standard of living the world has ever known. And, throughout August, I saw firsthand so many of you working hard to provide for your families.  So, I join with all of you in wishing everyone a very happy and safe Labor Day holiday...you've earned it.

It's ok to have strong opinions. However, saying White House Chief of Staff General John Kelly is a "disgrace to the uniform" and "has no honor" certainly crosses the line. General Kelly, like me and many other veterans - and unlike Congressman Gutierrez -  honorably served the United States in our military. In particular, General Kelly is a highly decorated veteran and a Gold Star Father.   If anyone is a disgrace in Washington, it's certainly not General Kelly.

I’ve heard from a number of elected officials and Cadiz residents about the post office closing. We are working with the Postal Service to see if there are alternative options to temporarily house the post office somewhere in Cadiz until in the situation with the building is resolved.

Earlier today, the House of Representatives passed disaster relief funding for Hurricane Harvey recovery efforts. The bill (H. Res 502) contains the full amount requested by the Administration, ensuring that FEMA can meet its current needs – and also be prepared for any additional disasters that may come. The legislation also included money to support the Small Business Administration’s disaster loan program to assist small businesses and homeowners as they start the process of rebuilding. Just as I voted for relief after Superstorm Sandy in 2012, I voted yes today; we must help those devastated by Hurricane Harvey.  It’s important to be there for our fellow Americans.

Earlier this morning, the House joined the Senate and President Trump to approve emergency funding to help in the hurricane recovery, and in anticipation of the damage that Hurricane Irma is predicted to cause in Florida this weekend. The vote in the House was 316-90; I voted yes. As I stated earlier this week, we are Americans first, and I’m hopeful that this spirit of unity will continue after the hurricanes pass. Getting relief to ravaged communities should not be a political football. And, let’s say a prayer for those in the path of Irma, and for those first responders standing by to risk their lives to save their fellow Americans.

Two renowned chefs from Taiwan, Chi-wen Chen and Ching-Long Huang, travel the world sharing their culinary skills. They go to five cities a year...and this year one of them is Youngstown - their first trip ever to Ohio. They are in town as part of a cultural exchange sponsored by the Youngstown/Warren Regional Chamber and the Chinese Association of Greater Youngstown Area.  Earlier this week, the two chefs taught a culinary class to students at the Mahoning County Career and Technical Center in Canfield, followed by serving members of the community dinner last night. I was honored to meet and welcome them to Ohio.

Every September 11 brings back memories. The images of that fateful morning 16 years ago still evoke pain and sorrow...and yes, anger.    Today, we pause to remember those we lost, and pray for the families whose loved ones were suddenly and senselessly taken from them. We are also eternally grateful to those heroes who sacrificed their lives that day – running into burning buildings and bringing down an aircraft turned into a missile - as well as those who are willing to pay the ultimate sacrifice today by defending all of us and preserving our freedoms – both our men and women in uniform and our first responders. That day we saw humanity’s capacity for evil, and in the ensuing aftermath, Americans responded with some of the finest examples of courage possible. We are a nation filled with heroes…and that day proved that the strength of America doesn’t come from its politicians or from its capital, it comes from our people.  Finally, as we remember September 11, 2001, let us resolve to look forward and address the challenges ahead with the same spirit of unity and national pride that we shared in the days and weeks that followed. I believe we’ve witnessed some of that recently as Americans have pulled together in the wake of two hurricanes. I hope it continues.
On New Year’s Day 2018, Americans should wake up with a more simple, affordable, and fair tax code that will create American jobs, reward success, and grow our economy.

This morning, the House of Representatives passed H.R. 3697, the Criminal Alien Gang Member Removal Act. This important legislation would ensure that alien gang members, such as those in MS-13, are kept off our streets by barring them entry to the United States, and detaining and removing them if they are criminal gang members or participate in gang activities. Believe it or not, it is not currently possible to deport gang members until they are convicted of an independent crime.   I’ve said it before, but it’s worth saying again – the primary duty of the federal government is to keep all Americans safe. It’s past time to ensure our immigration laws are not exploited by dangerous gang members. That cannot be tolerated…and that’s why I cast a yes vote for this bill.

This morning, I joined the Job Creators Network in front of the IRS Headquarters to highlight the need for tax reform and tax cuts. Today is the day that most small, family-run businesses in America make their estimated third quarter tax payments. These businesses are the backbone of the American economy - there are 29 million small businesses in the United States, which employ half of our workforce, and create two-thirds of all new jobs. For nearly a decade we’ve been limping along at an anemic economic growth rate.  President Reagan’s tax cuts changed that back in the 80’s when he set the stage for nearly two decades of sustained economic growth above three percent. We can do it again today with a similar tax cut on small business job creators.  The strength of America doesn’t reside in Washington D.C. - rather it lives in the indomitable spirit and heartbeat of the American people. Let’s empower the American people to innovate once again!

230 years ago today, our Founding Fathers signed and officially adopted the Constitution, the most influential document in American history. Our Constitution has now stood the test of time for over two centuries, and continues to be the framework of our great country.    On the last day of the convention, Benjamin Franklin stated, “I agree to this constitution with all its faults, if they are such, because I think a central government is necessary for us…I doubt too whether any other Convention we can obtain may be able to make a better Constitution.”   Benjamin Franklin’s words still ring true today. With only 17 amendments added to the Constitution since its adoption in 1787, our population stretches from coast to coast, our economy has expanded more than our Founding Fathers could have ever imagined, and our basic freedoms remain the driving force that inspires the spirit of the American people.

I’ve seen a lot of stories about local groups, students, churches, and others pitching in to help with hurricane relief. The 910th Airlift Wing, based at the Youngstown Air Reserve Station, is also lending a hand – more than 90 Reserve airmen are currently deployed and carrying out the base’s unique mosquito control mission. Since September 9th, the unit has treated more than 1.1 million acres – including areas with standing, polluted water.

Today marks the 70th anniversary of The National Security Act of 1947, which established the United States Air Force as a separate branch of the U.S. military.  As many of you know, I entered the Air Force in 1973 as an Airman Basic, and retired in 1999 as a Lieutenant Colonel after a career of over 26 years. My career in the Air Force and the core values we lived by - Integrity First, Service Before Self, and Excellence In All We Do - helped shape my life and affirmed my belief in all that makes America great. I am grateful to have had the opportunity to serve, and I wouldn’t trade that time for anything.  Though today may be the Air Force’s 70th birthday, we should recognize the sacrifice of all of those in all of our military branches and those currently serving the United States every day, both here and abroad.

Yesterday, I visited Edison High School in Richmond. The Edison Local School District  is comprised of the following communities in Jefferson County: Irondale, Stratton, Empire, Richmond, Amsterdam, and Bergholz.  Districtwide, the enrollment is around 1,700 students.    High School Principal Matt Morrison took time to show me some of the ongoing renovations, including new smartboards in classrooms. After that, I sat down with government students to take some of their questions...an engaging and enthusiastic bunch.  The school looks great, and I was impressed by the students and staff I met with!

Today, President Trump spoke with clarity and resolve at the United Nations addressing the greatest threats America, and our allies, face.   The President said “the scourge of our planet today is a small group of rogue regimes that violate every principle on which the United Nations is based.”  He put North Korea and Iran on notice, in front of the world, clearly articulating why the dangerous and provocative actions of each nation are unacceptable to America, and why they should be unacceptable to the U.N.   Those that continue to put partisanship ahead of country while our nation faces a nuclear madman in North Korea are misguided.  Like President John F. Kennedy during the Cuban Missile Crisis – the last time America was on the precipice of nuclear war - President Trump is demonstrating leadership, patience and restraint during this very volatile time.
Wishing a very happy New Year to all my Jewish friends celebrating Rosh Hashanah beginning tonight.  L’Shanah Tovah, may this be a sweet New Year for all!

I met with veterans and other seniors at the Glenwood Retirement Home in Marietta yesterday. Approximately 25 veterans from different eras, from WWII to Korea to Vietnam, live in this community. It was great to hear from them, both their questions about the important issues of the day, as well as some of their stories – and, I heard some good ones!  In many ways they’re a living history, and have borne witness to the sacrifices required to keep America free. It was a privilege to meet them.

“You have no idea how important you are!”   Yesterday I spoke to students at South Webster High School. Last year, social studies teacher Cyndy Hykes started a cross-curricular class on the opioid epidemic, encompassing all aspects of the issue: causes, treatment, judicial, government, and personal. I was glad to speak to these future leaders – and yes, let them know how important every one of them is to America’s future.    After speaking at the high school, I walked across the street to the elementary school to lead 5th and 6th graders in writing letters of appreciation to local veterans.
eNews: America Needs Tax Reform - and I want YOUR input!

I always stand for the national anthem. It’s how I was raised…and, after 26-plus years in the Air Force, it’s not something I even have to think about.  I would guess it’s second nature to almost all of you, too.   I was very saddened by what I watched at some of the NFL games this past weekend.   We’ve got a lot of challenges facing our country, and whether millionaire athletes are standing for the national anthem is far down on my list of pressing topics. Don't get me wrong, I certainly think they should stand and pay respect to our flag...we've done that for generations here in America.  But, whether or not they do or they don’t ultimately has no effect on me or you - the people I serve. Anyone, including these athletes, who feels the need to express their grievances by protesting during our national anthem is exercising their constitutional right.  But, it’s also the right of the fans to turn off the tv and not attend games.  Now, I might have said it a little differently than President Trump did. But whether you are a professional athlete, a coal miner, a stay-at-home-mom, a truck driver, doctor, lawyer, or any other hardworking American citizen, your freedoms and liberties that exist in abundance here in the United States are protected by the men and women who choose to wear wear our nation's military uniform and stand in harm’s way.  And, those brave warriors put their lives on the line every day to defend those freedoms and our flag, Old Glory.  Sadly, I think that is what is getting lost in the rhetoric right now.

Yesterday, the House passed the Increasing Opportunity and Success for Children and Parents through Evidence-Based Home Visiting Act. This bill would reauthorize the Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) Program through Fiscal Year 2022. The program seeks to strengthen and improve home visiting services to families in at-risk communities. The program helps support state and local efforts to provide voluntary, evidence-based, outcome-focused home visiting services to parents and children living in communities which put them at risk of poor social and health outcomes. The evidence-based programs within this legislation have also been proven to help break the cycle of poverty and empower families. I voted yes.

As it stands now, the federal government, and some states, receive revenue in the form of royalties and permit fees from energy companies that develop energy on federally owned land, such as the Wayne National Forest. However, Ohio counties do not directly receive any of this revenue. This is wrong, and the POWER Act (H.R. 3846), which I introduced today, would remedy this. My legislation calls for 20% of this revenue to be redirected back to the counties from where those federal lands are located, where the funding can be used to support education initiatives and road improvements. There is no additional expense to the taxpayers in this bill.    I’ve introduced similar legislation before, and I will keep doing so until it passes and is signed into law. You, the taxpayers, deserve to share the benefits derived from energy development on local lands – it’s a simple issue of fairness.

I spoke on the House floor yesterday regarding the veteran suicide epidemic.  The statistics are staggering - and painful.  On average, 20 veterans per day take their own lives. These heroes were so much more than a statistic; I shared just one of the many heart-wrenching stories I’ve received from my constituents. I urge my colleagues and our federal agencies to all work together to help put a stop to this disturbing trend.

Today, I joined Senator Portman and Congressman Wenstrup in welcoming Secretary of Energy Rick Perry to Southern Ohio. We toured the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant and the American Centrifuge Project facility.    It was a great opportunity to demonstrate the significant work being done there, its importance to the local economy, and the potential for future economic development and job creation.. We were also able to show Secretary Perry firsthand the existing infrastructure in place at the American Centrifuge Project, and discussed the critical importance of a domestic uranium enrichment program to America’s national security.

Good to catch up with some retired coal miners who were in Washington this week, along with the United Mine Workers of America, to discuss some of the important issues miners – both retired and presently employed - face. These folks have contributed so much to keeping the lights in here in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.  We are extremely grateful for all their hard work.  Thanks for stopping by, folks!

There are no words that could possibly express my sadness and horror over the tragic events last night in Las Vegas.  The shooter and any accomplices were the worst kind of cowards. My heart and prayers  go out to everyone affected. From the reports I’ve seen, it looks like the officers from the Las Vegas PD who ran to the trouble and saved countless lives are the heroes.

Today, I joined executives from PTT Global Chemical, the company considering building an ethane cracker plant in Belmont County. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) was signed today with JobsOhio, which is yet another positive development. The MOU between the two calls for a joint established development plan for community infrastructure. The project – which would be the largest construction project in the history of Ohio –continues to gather momentum.

The American people deserve a tax system that is simpler, fairer, and makes America more competitive. It’s been over 30 years since the last major tax code overhaul, and we now have an opportunity to deliver real middle-class tax relief, fuel major economic growth, and create good-paying jobs.  Before I was elected to Congress, I led a tax-reform effort in Ohio - this issue was one of the reasons I ran for office in the first place. Fixing our broken tax code to provide much needed tax relief is very important to me, and this plan is about helping ALL Americans – and especially the Middle Class – improve their quality of life. We must get this done…and I am optimistic that we will. I joined the Fox Business Network this week to discuss  our tax relief program and the current Republican framework; you can watch the video below.

As a father of 4 and a grandfather of 6, I have been very outspoken in my pro-life beliefs.    Yesterday, the House passed H.R. 36, the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, also known as Micah’s Law. I co-sponsored the bill, and voted yes. Most Americans agree that an unborn child, at 20 weeks, has developed into a baby with moving limbs and growing hair – and is the mark at which unborn babies can feel pain. Saving the lives of babies from painful, late-term abortions is an important step in showing compassion for the most helpless and vulnerable among us.

The House is debating and voting on the FY 2018 budget this week. The Building a Better America budget balances by 2027, promotes economic growth, ensures a strong national defense, improves the sustainability of Medicare, and reforms federal programs by improving accountability. Importantly, this budget strengthens programs that seniors and some of our most vulnerable citizens rely on –and we must ensure that these programs continue for future generations.   BOTH political parties in Washington, at times, have refused to abide by the simple principle that hard-working American families must adhere to – living within your means. Our national debt is now over $20 trillion...a number that is so high it is not even comprehensible. If excessive Washington spending and debt are not brought under control, the consequences will be dire.   I spoke on the House floor earlier today about the budget resolution:

Today, I hosted my second "Manufacturing Your Future” event for young people in our region.  This year, I partnered with Zane State College and the Ohio Valley Educational Service Center.  I spoke to approximately 100 high school students from Guernsey and Noble counties, and then accompanied them on a tour of local manufacturing businesses to learn more about what those businesses do.    The main goal of the event was to help inform young people about some of the opportunities they have after high school, specifically in the manufacturing industry. In order for our region to take full advantage of the opportunities coming our way, our people must be ready, trained, and prepared to fill these emerging jobs. Today's discussions and in-person tours helped explain and demonstrate some of the options to students who will soon enter the workforce.  The students were very engaged, and I was encouraged by their questions and enthusiasm.

The recent decision by the Trump Administration to eliminate federally mandated contraception and abortifacients coverage in employee health care plans was an important step to safeguard constitutionally protected freedom of religion and conscience rights. No one should have to provide or pay for services to which they object on religious principle.  The freedom to practice one's faith is one of our most basic constitutional rights as Americans. This freedom was trampled on by the Obama Administration; but, that's now changing.

I strongly support EPA Administrator Pruitt's decision to formally end the coal-job-killing set of regulations that the Obama Administration put in place.  Last year, the Supreme Court put the so-called "Clean Power Plan" on hold due to numerous concerns over this sweeping regulatory policy.  I'm heartened to see the Trump Administration continuing to undo President Obama's War on Coal.  This is a big win for Ohio.

It is no secret that the United States is in the midst of an opioid epidemic…one that can be felt in virtually every community across the country. Earlier this morning, I shared a story to spotlight some of the good work being done in Southeastern Ohio to help combat this scourge, and to let people know about some of the positive developments taking place.   I highlighted Field of Hope, a faith-based, non-profit, treatment facility that assists area families ravaged by poverty and drug abuse. In the video below, I talk more about the facility’s history. During a visit there, I heard some incredibly powerful and touching stories, and I witnessed the good work they are doing firsthand.    Congress has an important role to play in supplementing and enabling the work being done by organizations like Field of Hope.  I’ve also been encouraged by the recent efforts of private payers, providers, pharmacists, and patient groups to address the addiction crisis through increased awareness, prescribing guidelines, and new treatment options.  I believe Congress can play a role in ensuring that all prescribers are equipped with education in pain management so they can provide effective pain treatments for patients and timely intervention for those who are addicted.

Today’s action by President Trump to begin righting the ship on America’s healthcare system is welcome news for the many Americans who rely on Obamacare plans that have become unaffordable. Nearly 50 percent of all counties across the country will have only one health care provider option under Obamacare next year. That’s not leaving much of a choice in plans for the American people – which was one of President Obama’s major promises when he signed Obamacare. A recent study shows that the majority of American’s choosing to pay the penalties for not having an Obamacare approved insurance plan are low income and middle-class Americans.  Today’s action sets the table for more affordable healthcare options for these hardworking Americans who have witnessed their premiums and deductibles skyrocket. Today’s action by President Trump was necessary, because the Senate failed to follow the House’s lead and pass legislation to repeal Obamacare, reduce healthcare costs, increase healthcare choices for the American people, and put healthcare decisions back in the hands of patients and their doctors. Yesterday, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly voted yes to H.R. 849, the Protecting Seniors’ Access to Medicare Act. This important bill would repeal Obamacare’s Independent Payment Advisory Board, otherwise known as IPAB – a board of bureaucrats set up to make healthcare decisions on behalf of America’s seniors.   I’ve been against IPAB ever since I was first elected to Congress; this legislation is an additional step to place decisions back in the hands of health care providers and the patients they serve.    Specifically, under Obamacare, IPAB set yearly caps in Medicare spending that ultimately hurt the quality of care Medicare beneficiaries receive, and threatened a patient’s ability to ensure they have access to the health care they need, when they need it. Every patient's need is different, and repealing this one-size-fits-all regulation is a win for rural communities and patients that rely on quality, affordable healthcare choices.     H.R. 849  passed by a vote of 307-111 - with 76 Democrats joining Republicans in voting for this repeal.  I urge my Senate colleagues to approve this important legislation.

Last week, the House passed legislation that would reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), Community Health Centers (CHCs), and several other important public health programs - all while reducing deficits for future generations of Americans.     In Ohio, 30 percent of children have health insurance coverage through CHIP; the program provides children from economically disadvantaged families access to world class health care.  Community Health Centers (CHCs) provide community-based, patient-centered care to over 623,000 Ohioans at over 280 locations, including 24 locations in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.  Together, CHIP and CHCs provide a vital safety net to low-income and uninsured Ohioans to ensure their health care needs are met in their communities.    Funding these programs is vital to ensure low-income and uninsured children, families, and seniors can continue to access quality and affordable healthcare. The House bill I supported includes responsible spending offsets that cover the costs of these programs and actually reduces the debt in future years.  Now, the bill heads to the Senate where I hope they will follow the House’s lead and pass this important legislation.

Yesterday the House passed H.R. 3441, the Save Local Business Act, and I enthusiastically voted yes.  The law currently states that two or more employers can be considered joint employers for making a business agreement that “indirectly” or “potentially” impacts their employees day-to-day responsibilities and working environment. This unfair scheme discourages larger companies from contracting with small businesses, threatens the freedom of independent business owners, and makes it harder for employees working multiple jobs to achieve the American Dream.  H.R. 3441 clarifies the joint employer standard under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), and states that two or more employers must have “actual, direct, and immediate” control over employees to be considered joint employers. By clarifying this standard, hard-working Americans and independent business owners are given stability in the workplace and are protected from future bureaucratic overreach. It is common-sense legislation.

The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act (H.R. 38) is a very common-sense bill that simply seeks to protect law-abiding citizens who are attempting to exercise their constitutional rights and comply with concealed carry laws. It passed in the House today 231-198.   The bill, which I co-sponsored, would allow law-abiding citizens with a state-issued concealed carry license or permit to conceal a handgun in any other state that allows concealed carry. The individual would need to have a valid photo ID, a valid concealed carry permit, and cannot be federally prohibited from possessing or receiving a firearm. Under this legislation, individuals would still have to follow all local laws—state, county and municipal — even if they differ from the state where they got the original permit.   H.R. 38 does not deal with access to weapons: it has nothing to do with the purchase of guns, access to guns, and doesn’t change federal background check laws. What it would do, however, is empower law-abiding citizens with the ability to protect themselves from criminals, and ensure that our Second Amendment rights do not disappear when we cross state lines.  As a concealed carry permit holder myself, I understand the current frustration many have.  I am hopeful that the Senate will follow the House’s lead and pass this important legislation.

As another year winds down, today we take a special pause to reflect on the anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor that expanded WWII into the Pacific theater. This day, 76 years ago, America’s resolve was tested, and a new devotion to country was ignited.   The attack on Pearl Harbor was a shock to the nation, and even today it serves as a reminder that the American spirit will always persevere over those that seek to harm the United States and threaten the freedoms we hold so dear. The Japanese Empire did a lot of damage that day, but they couldn’t destroy our resolve. It was a major miscalculation on their part.     As President Franklin Roosevelt stated in his address to the American people following the attack, “With confidence in our armed forces – with the unbounding determination of our people – we will gain the inevitable triumph.” The men and women of the Greatest Generation proved him right.   May God Bless those who have served in our nation’s armed forces, and those who continue to serve our great country!

Jerusalem has been, and always will be, the capital of Israel - unless the Jewish people themselves determine otherwise.  There is no question that the city is the religious epicenter of Judaism and the focus of governance in the country, and now the United States will recognize the city as the capital of Israel. On three separate occasions, the House and Senate supported recognizing Jerusalem as Israel’s capital, including the passage of the Jerusalem Embassy Act in 1995.  But, that official designation from the White House never happened...until yesterday. Ignoring the physical location of the Israeli Knesset and the office of the Prime Minister in Jerusalem does not bring the Middle East any closer to peace.   This was the right thing to do, and it’s another  campaign promise that President Trump has now kept.   I also applaud President Trump’s announcement that the State Department will begin preparations to move the American embassy from Tel Aviv to Israel’s capital city, Jerusalem.  In my view, moving the American Embassy to Jerusalem and recognizing it as Israel’s capital sends a strong message of America’s support for our great ally and the undeniable right of Israel to exist.

This afternoon I introduced two new pieces of legislation regarding American liquefied natural gas exports. The U.S. is currently the world’s largest producer of natural gas, with trillions of cubic feet of recoverable natural gas beneath our feet. We should be doing all we can to take advantage of this abundant resource, and it is my hope that these bills will help further that goal.  The Unlocking Our Domestic LNG Potential Act (H.R. 4605) will allow our domestic LNG suppliers to compete freely on the world market by streamlining the federal approval process. Additionally, The Ensuring Small Scale LNG Certainty and Access Act (H.R. 4606) would codify the Department of Energy’s recent efforts to encourage the exports of small volumes of natural gas, as countries in the Caribbean, Central America, and South America look to the United States to meet their natural gas needs.   It’s critically important that we take advantage of this opportunity we’ve been blessed with – there is no doubt that LNG exports are creating opportunities and improving the quality of life for hard working families in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio.

I support an open Internet, and there is a better way to ensure consumer protections without disrupting the free flow of information and innovation that has made it a cornerstone of the 21st Century economy. The 2015 heavy-handed rules from the Obama administration stifled investment in rural communities, like those in Eastern and Southeastern Ohio, and created uncertainty for Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in meeting the requirements of those rules. The way to protect consumers is to allow the Federal Trade Commission – who is well-equipped to do so - to crack down on those who would abuse open access.   According to a recent economic analysis, domestic broadband capital expansion declined by $3.6 billion in the years since the Obama regulations were implemented, a 5.6 percent decline relative to 2014 levels. Going back to the way the Internet was governed prior to 2015, and giving everyone – including those in rural communities like ours – access will continue to open new avenues for telemedicine, distance learning, and future innovations.
